nodes.bodyText: Is this just to avoid creating the Instant object?
Exactly. Every little bit helps when you're performance testing at 10K.
nit: should this rather be not equal?

Yes, I do believe a few sprints back I made a change around this logic because of some encoding confusion.
I believe the SDK encodes the message also. So when subscribing we have to decode the whole message first.
Let me dig in and confirm.

The publish and subscribe logic you pasted is correct/similar for both acceptance and performance.
In both cases only the first 8 bytes are read by Longs.fromByteArray() so the rest of the message doesn't really matter and the accuracy of the publish instant being retrieved isn't impacted. Are you seeing cases where this is not the case and publish times are wrong?
The base64 encoding was added to ensure preservation of data during transport. I believe when the byte array had negative numbers the size of the data was getting modified during transport with the sdk and resulting incorrect Instant values when converted.

I don't think it's a bug (unless you're seeing bad times) so much as an opportunity to improve the efficiency of the logic.
I'm okay with byte array concatenation so far as it works. The point was for the subscribe codes in all our tests to work regardless of where the transactions were published from. Service load testing/ mirror acceptance/performance tests - they should all work.
Try a few runs after your change and check for error cases where erroneous Instants times are created on the subscribe time e.g. EPOCH/max or a time in the future.
That was the original bug seen that prompted the base64 encoding
Discussed offline. This logic has been changed from base64 to raw bytes and above is no longer applicable.

nit: I think we should start to make it a practice of commenting on multi stage reactive flows.
They tend to be the places where order is important and where logic is swapped in and out.
So it would help for future management to be clear on the choices applied here.
Sure, will add some javadocs

This should be moved outside of the for loop and checked once right?
Since properties doesn't change per scenario and if properties.isEnabled() is false it doesn't matter whether the scenarios are enabled.
I had it like that but I later put it inside as it avoids an extra level of nesting and if statement and accomplishes the same thing. But I can move it back up if it eases your mind.
Is there a reason to set the receipt here if it's already set in init()?
No, just as a form of documentation when reading the test case in isolation.
Same thing, is there a reason to set the record to the same value set in the init?
No, just as a form of documentation when reading the test case in isolation.
can catch IllegalArgumentException which is thrown if bytes has fewer than 8 elements
That shouldn't be possible since I check if bytes.length < Long.BYTES and return right above this.

yes.
I meant If we catch the exception, we don't need to check the length & copy the buffer before calling Longs.fromByteArray

I'd still have to check if null as Longs.fromByteArray doesn't. But in general, it's better to use a conditional as it's an order of magnitude more performant than exception handling, especially during performance testing.
double acquire for the first PublishRequest, is this intended?

It's intended. The RateLimiter's first acquire always occurs instantaneously since it doesn't have anything to compare against. Discarding that first acquire makes the numbers more accurate but more importantly fixes the issue with setting Double.MIN_NORMAL for TPS to never generate a message like I do for inactive scenarios in CompositeTransactionGenerator.
I'll add a comment so this is clear.

I see.
Not related to the conversation above, I do think we need a single global rate limiter instead of one per scenario.
One rate limiter per scenario can cause spikes of transactions. For example, there are two enabled scenarios of 25.0 tps (A) and 75.0 tps (B), the extreme case is for a group of 100 transactions, the distribution is the first 25 are all for A so it takes the whole second and leaves the next 75 for B generated back to back in one shot.
A single global rate limiter will make the transactions evenly spaced time wise.
We can consider it in the future once proven via testing
this is percent + 1 out of 100  when percent is not 0 or 100. (count % 100) < percent should work and no special handling of 0 and 100 is needed.
Will change

subscriberProperties.getLimit() - counter.get() can be negative when subscriberProperties.getLimit() is 0 and counter is not 0
limit should be set 0 if getLimit() is 0; otherwise it should be set to getLimit() - counter.get()
That's why I added the extra call to java.lang.Math. Unfortunately I put Math.min() and I meant Math.max(). Will correct.
endTime should stay the same when it's calculated based on duration; it should not be the current startTime + duration when retrying
Correct, which is why I store the endTime from the previous run so this code is never reached on retry.
This class was removed as a result of removing the manual bean validation.  It can be added back for the message size check, just a heads up that there may be conflicts.
Yep, removed.
Thank you, I think this will really help going forward.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -51,6 +51,14 @@
     @Resource
     private Subscriber subscriber;
 
+    /**
+     * Constructs a reactive flow for publishing and subscribing to transactions. The transaction generator will run on
+     * a single thread and generate transactions as fast as possible. Next, a parallel Flux will concurrently publish
+     * those transactions to the main nodes. Finally, a subscriber will receive every published transaction response and
+     * validate whether that transaction was received by the mirror node APIs.
+     *
+     * @return the subscribed flux
+     */

nodes.bodyText: nit: think we should set a max on message size?
Sure, I can add @Max(6144) but it won't be truly accurate since 6K is the max including the signatures and other metadata.

q: Do you think the Node Properties would be better located in a config file for easier on the fly modifications should a need arise. That way no code hotfix is needed.
All be it I guess should that need arise you could temporarily use the OTHER network and configure it as needed even in the case of test/main/preview net.
Figured might make it more flexible in config file than java file.

nodes.bodyText: Nit: Should this be marked final if the intent is to never allow retries?

If it was final I could just remove the variable and hardcode it. The intent is to make retries configurable. Later we might be able to do this generically for all transaction types in which case we can make this a publisher property.
That makes sense, just in this instance it being used in a NonRetryableConsensusMessageSubmitTransaction implies it would never be configured otherwise.
Naming things is hard. Counter suggestion?
Hardest part of coding.  Maybe RetryConfigurableConsensusMessageSubmitTransaction?
Updated

nit: at most loads probably negligible but might be more accurate to get system mills at start of method and use here.
Just removing the case of added time if this process is moving slow
Will move
